column35: News Article

ICE continues to send detainees to the Alabama jail, including individuals who have come through facilities with confirmed coronavirus infections. Officials at Etowah consolidated two units into one, doubling the number of men sharing the space overnight. Late March, detainees asked to be screened by a nurse for Covid-19. It was a basic screening, Golding stressed, not a test for the coronavirus. Golding said a nurse told him he was “symptomatic” and provided him with Advil and allergy medication. Several other detainees were told the same — none were placed in quarantine. Also appears to be a lack of supplies like soap. 
BUT this is what ICE says: “There is no one in ICE custody at the Etowah County facility with suspected Covid-19. Rumors to the contrary are false and needlessly spread fear through misinformation.” Detainees now required to wear masks. Persons detained who are held on the county side for short term processing (up to 72 hours) are still being transferred in and out, up to 10 people a week. There's a bus that goes from Etowah to Louisiana (to LaSalle - Pine Prairie and Adams also receivers) and back twice weekly.

column2: 2739 E Las Vegas St, Colorado Springs, CO 80906
column35: 3 sheriff deputies who worked at jail tested positive, including one death. 8 inmates in isolation because of flu-like symtoms as of April 3. In statement to inmate families, Sheriff's Office wrote: we know it is likely a number of inmates and staff will become infected." 41-year old Deputy Jeff Hopkins died from the virus. Some wards have individual cells, others have bays with each beds each. Has 100 tests. Jail's normal population is 1,500 but was reduced to 1,087 due to COVID-19.

column2: 3900 N Powerline Rd, Pompano Beach, FL 33073
column35: U.S. District Judge Marcia Cooke said crowded condiitons exposed inmates to COVID, violating constitutional rights, and forcing jail to depopulate to level of 75% capacity. Social distancing at facility impossible. ICE has failed to provide detainees in facilities with masks, soap, and cleaning supplies. Bunks 12 inches apart.  Paul Chavez of Southern Poverty Law Center's Immigrant Justice Project: "We look forward to holding ICE accountable to this order and will be filing for class action certification soon. The urgency of the situation cannot be understated. By ignoring the advice of doctors and public health experts, the agency is knowingly putting detained peoples' lives in grave danger."

U.S. District Judge Marcia Cooke said crowded condiitons exposed inmates to COVID, violating constitutional rights, and forcing jail to depopulate to level of 75% capacity. Social distancing at facility impossible. ICE has failed to provide detainees in facilities with masks, soap, and cleaning supplies.

8 ICE officials have COVID. 350 detainees in quarantine. In a sworn statement filed in Miami federal court, Liana J. Castano, the acting director in charge of the Krome facility, said eight staff members have tested positive for the virus and that 350 detainees, whom the government has identified as being exposed to the illness are being quarantined together, a practice that U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement calls “cohorting.” U.S. District Judge Marcia Cooke said crowded condiitons exposed inmates to COVID, violating constitutional rights, and forcing jail to depopulate to level of 75% capacity. Social distancing at facility impossible. ICE has failed to provide detainees in facilities with masks, soap, and cleaning supplies. Southn Poverty Law Report from 2019: "While individual pod capacity is supposed to be about 65, some detained individuals estimate there are 100 or more people in their pods, a level that, we were told by a detained person, feels “dangerously overcrowded.”
4 staffers test positive.

column2: 3424 Hwy 252 E P.O. Box 248, Folkston, GA, 31537
column35: “We basically have to hunger strike to get what we need,” says Jose Miranda-Gonzalez, a man detained in Georgia’s Folkston ICE Processing center. -- Soap and cleaning products rationed so detainees have stopped eating to pressure staff to provide more supplies. People who cannot afford it do not have soap to wash hands. GEO Group response: "We strongly reject these unfounded allegations, which we believe are being instigated by outside groups with political agendas…. Our ICE Processing Centers provide access to regular handwashing with clean water and soap in all housing areas and throughout each facility.” ICE response: “I’m not aware of any hunger strikes related to soap and hygiene products,” Danielle Bennet wrote in an e-mail.

Freedom for Immigrants Detention Hotline (4/23): "There are 70 people in a room. We have protective gear and access to soap, but it doesn'y matter because the facility is too overcrowded and we are not receving sufficient medical care. [My friend] is showing symptoms of COVID-19 and the guards are only giving him aspirin." Source - Family on Freedom for Immigrants 4/7: "When a protest was staged, armed guards were brought in to quell the protests. There is no PPE for anyone detained there. My partner led a protest to at least get food delivered so they did not have to travel between cell blocks. He said the reaction to the flu was much better than this. He and his cellmates are forced to clean their own blocks. Additionally, detainees are refusing to cook as part of the hunger strike so there are delays on food delivery."

ICE mandates private prisons to serve 3 meals a day but to keep costs down, breakfast served at 3:30 AM and meals are sparse or days old, according to current inmate. Once per week, given a tiny soap bar that lats 1 day--the rest of soap needs to be paid for out-of-pocket.

First three cases on 4/9. 4/27: Two employees of the detention center carry the virus home, where it gets transferred to more people, who carry it to the grocery store, where it gets transferred to more people, etc., etc. That’s how this happens, folks, even in Pulaski County. "Detainees, and their advocates, say they are not receiving timely information about outbreaks in the facilities where they are housed, or adequate access to masks, hand sanitizer and cleaning supplies." "County officials have sought to tamp down concerns in Pulaski County as they’ve worried over whether news of an outbreak could lead to protests among detainees and immigrant rights’ groups and cost them a lucrative contract with Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE). Jail fees bring in more than $8 million annually to the county of fewer than 5,500 people." -- "“You know, it’s just, you know, there’s not just a whole lot more we can say at the moment without jeopardizing Pulaski County’s relationship with ICE and the ICE contract. That’s what I just wish everybody would realize,” said Rex Wilburn, Pulaski County Board chairman, after the health department confirmed the first three cases among detainees there on April 9."

Help!!!” Marlen messaged her daughter. By the end of the repressive crackdown, guards had pepper sprayed over 70 people, including Marlen.

Privately operated. At the nearby privately operated Elizabeth Detention Center⁠, inmates complained of not having even hand sanitizer in their close quarters, and that guards were not using masks or gloves. One medical worker there had a positive test last week.

Cases at the detention center make up about just more than a third of all cases in Genesee County. The number of cases at the detention center was first listed by Genesee and Orleans Health Departments this past weekend.
The center already has released about half of its population. The center has 650 beds but now has about 320 detainees.
“Being detained here, we are like the proverbial lamb waiting to be slaughtered,” said the letter, which was sent to Justice for Migrant Families WNY. “None of the Security, Food Service, Medical, Maintenance or Janitorial Staff are prohibited from leaving at the end of their shifts. They go home, go out, go shopping, all normal activities. However, they are the only ones who would introduce this dread killer into our midst.” HUNGER STRIKES
